Good explainer on lightning. (But use of IOU may give wrong intuition there is no counter-party risk, each LN transaction is a real Bitcoin bearer ownership tx that can be broadcast to the main chain to claim, if the owner grows impatient with responsiveness of the other party).

True. It's defined in the sense that the drivechain theft is defined, and then there's a hope that Bitcoin miners and users agree to stop the theft via soft-fork with the proof being to the community rather than an automated compact SPV proof.

Sure, but as we know media doesn't get subtlety "Bitcoin hacked vs sidechains hacked". And as a principle having opt-in reduced security/decentralisation tradeoffs is a reasonable choice. Lightning is one such trade-off this is another one.

I think miners just put whatever highest paying drive chain hash in the Bitcoin block (paid in BTC fees) and rely on economics to sort the rest out. Plus drive chain withdraw is intentionally slow (eg 3mo) to allow humans to SF block miners stealing all.
